trigger: Transcriptional activity of core binding factor-alpha ( <extra_id_0> AML1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and beta subunits on murine leukemia virus enhancer cores .

Core binding factor ( CBF ) , also known as polyomavirus enhancer - binding protein 2 and SL3 enhancer factor 1 , is a mammalian transcription factor that binds to an element termed the core within the enhancers of the murine leukemia virus family of retroviruses .

The core elements of the SL3 virus are important genetic determinants of the ability of this virus to induce T-cell lymphomas and the transcriptional activity of the viral long terminal repeat in T lymphocytes .

CBF consists of two subunits , a DNA binding subunit , <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and a second subunit , <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , that stimulates the DNA binding activity of <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

One of the genes that encodes a <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit is <extra_id_0> AML1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , also called <extra_id_0> Cbf alpha 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
This locus is rearranged by chromosomal translocations in human myeloproliferative disorders and leukemias .

An exogenously expressed <extra_id_0> Cbf alpha 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - encoded subunit ( <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> 2-451 ) stimulated transcription from the SL3 enhancer in P19 and HeLa cells .
Activity was mediated through the core elements .
Three different isoforms of <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were also tested for transcriptional activity on the SL3 enhancer .

The longest form , <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - 187 , increased the transcriptional stimulation by <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> 2-451 twofold in HeLa cells , although it had no effect in P19 cells .

Transcriptional activation by <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> required binding to the <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit , as a form of <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that lacked binding ability , <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - 148 , failed to increase activity .
These results indicated that at least in certain cell types , the maximum activity of CBF required both subunits .
They also provided support for the hypothesis that CBF is a factor in T lymphocytes that is responsible for recognition of the SL3 cores .
We also examined whether CBF could distinguish a 1-bp difference between the enhancer core of SL3 and the core of the nonleukemogenic virus , Akv .
This difference strongly affects transcription in T cells and leukemogenicity of SL3 .

However , no combination of <extra_id_0> CBF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CBF beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunits that we tested was able to distinguish the 1-bp difference in transcription assays .
Thus , a complete understanding of how T cells recognize the SL3 core remains to be elucidated .
